meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford on Tue Jan 27, the snow amount looks minor for Michigan standards (around 0.45" total, mainly between ~3–5 AM, then tapering off by/near daybreak). The bigger impact is the brief mixed precip/icing signal overnight (light freezing rain around ~2 AM and again near ~6 AM) combined with very cold temperatures and wind chills around -10°F to -15°F through the morning. If roads/bridges glaze even lightly, that can be a high-impact travel hazard despite low snowfall totals. Winds are modest (15–20 mph) so widespread blowing/drifting is not the main issue. Net: low-to-moderate snow-day potential overall, but a moderate risk of a DELAY/closure if freezing rain creates slick roads during the early commute window (roughly 5–8 AM).

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, mostly light snow/showers (around 0.5 inch) with temps in the teens and moderate wind (15–20 mph). This is a very common late-January pattern in West Michigan: nuisance/light accumulation, periodic reduced visibility, but roads usually remain manageable with normal plowing/salting.

Light mixed precip signal overnight (brief freezing rain/freezing drizzle indications) followed by colder, windy daytime. Even tiny glaze amounts can spike crash risk and occasionally drive delays/closures if it hits right before the AM commute and treatment is limited.

Wind-chill driven decisions: air temps near 1–16°F with sustained wind ~15–20 mph producing wind chills roughly in the -5°F to -15°F range around early morning. In Michigan, closures for cold are more typical when wind chills are at/colder than about -15°F (especially if prolonged near/below -20°F). This pattern is near the lower threshold but not an automatic-closure setup by itself.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in the Rockford (Kent County/Grand Rapids-area) region routinely features teens for highs, single digits to low teens at night, and periodic light snow/lake-effect bursts. Schools typically stay open with light accumulations; closures are more commonly tied to significant overnight snow (often 8–10+ inches with bad timing), true blizzard conditions/whiteouts, meaningful ice, or extreme/prolonged wind chills (commonly <= -15°F, especially when widespread).
unusual_factors: A Cold Weather Advisory is mentioned in your dataset, signaling impactful wind chills overnight into Tuesday morning (this increases the chance of operational disruptions, especially for bus stops and long waits).

The hourly forecast includes brief 'light freezing rain' indications overnight (around 2 AM and 6 AM). Even if totals are tiny, a thin glaze on untreated roads/sidewalks can be disproportionately disruptive at morning bus/parent drop-off time.
Visibility is forecast to be reduced at times (day avg vis ~3 miles; several overnight hours ~1 mile), consistent with snow showers/mist and potentially slick travel.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits in the West Michigan snow belt influence zone: lake-effect bands can produce sharp gradients over a few miles. One corridor can be much worse than another, which can complicate district-wide decisions.
Rural roads north/east of the Grand Rapids metro (common bus routes for Rockford-area coverage) can become slick faster than main arterials, especially before dawn treatment.
infrastructure_considerations: Michigan districts are accustomed to winter driving and typically do not close for ~0.5 inch of snow alone; roads are usually treated unless rates are high or icing occurs.
The bigger operational risk here is early-morning slick spots (bridges/overpasses/untreated neighborhood roads) combined with very cold wind chills at bus-stop time.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor-to-moderate: local hills/river valleys can create pockets of drifting and slicker conditions on shaded/low-traffic roads, but the forecast wind (max ~19 mph) is not a classic drifting/blizzard driver without heavier snow.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall snow-day likelihood for Tuesday, 2026-01-27 in Rockford is LOW to LOW-MODERATE. Snow amount is small (~1.15 cm / ~0.45 in) and not near typical closure thresholds. The main watch-outs are (1) the brief freezing-rain signal overnight and (2) near-threshold wind chills around early morning. If icing is confirmed near 4–8 AM or visibility drops to near-whiteout in a localized band, a delay is more plausible than a full closure; otherwise, expect normal operations with possible spotty slick travel.

safety_recommendations: Primary concern is a pre-dawn wintry mix (light freezing rain around 2 AM and again near 6 AM) combined with light snow (roughly 3–5 AM). This timing can create slick bridges/overpasses and patchy black ice for the 6–8 AM school travel window, even though total snow is low (~1.15 cm / ~0.5 in).
Expect plows/salt to improve main routes by/after daybreak, but neighborhood and rural connectors may remain slick longer—especially shaded roads and untreated intersections.

Bus/parent drop-off areas: allow extra time for lot treatment and for crews to clear/refreeze-prone spots (curbs, sidewalks, crosswalk ramps). With temps staying well below freezing all day (high ~16°F, low ~1°F), any treated meltwater can refreeze.
Advise slower speeds, longer following distances, and extra caution on bridges, ramps, and hills Tuesday morning. Consider staging salt on known trouble spots before 6 AM if possible.

Cold exposure is a secondary student-safety issue: wind chills near/below 0°F (and potentially below -10°F at times) during early morning can create frostbite risk for walkers and bus stop waits; ensure students are covered and minimize outdoor wait time.

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement: All experts converge on (a) minor snow totals, (b) a narrow pre-dawn hazard window, and (c) the main operational risk being slick spots (bridges/untreated roads) rather than deep snow. They also agree a delay is more plausible than a full closure.
2) Disagreement: The only major conflict was wind chill (Weather.com showed <= -20°F earlier). Web verifier resolved this: official NWS point forecast for Rockford MI indicates wind chills around ~-8°F overnight and ~-2°F Tuesday (commute window not near -20°F). So the automatic cold-closure trigger is NOT supported.
3) Plow timing math: Snow/mix ends ~6:30; that’s essentially 0–1 hour before buses. Highways/arterials get continuous cycles, but neighborhood streets and rural bus-route connectors often won’t be “good” until after a daylight pass (~8:30–10:30). That timing supports delay risk but not a strong full-closure signal.
4) Ice: Present as a risk, but likely *trace-to-spotty* (meteorologist notes extremely small QPF during freezing-rain hours). Enough for isolated slickness; not a widespread glaze event.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel found no confirmed Tue closures/delays for Rockford or key neighbors; closings pages show minimal activity → no domino boost.
6) Power: Kent County outages extremely low (~12 customers). No evidence of a broader outage event → no power-based bump.
7) Wind chill verification: NWS confirms not <= -20°F for Rockford → no near-automatic closure.
8) What would make me wrong: If freezing drizzle/freezing rain is more efficient than forecast and creates widespread black ice (especially around 5:30–7:00 AM) OR if an early-morning crash cluster/road incident pattern emerges OR a localized power/heat outage affects multiple buildings.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology (25%) + Safety (20%) + History (15%) all point to low closure odds because totals are small and improvements occur after daybreak; Safety/Infrastructure highlight commute timing and secondary-road traction as the main issue. News (15%) provides no confirmed closure momentum. Infrastructure (10%) suggests arterials OK but neighborhoods/rural still slick. Power (10%) low outages. Web verifier (5%) removes the -20°F trigger. Net result: a closure is possible but not likely; I land on ~20% for a full snow day closure (with higher probability for a 2-hour delay than for a closure).

alternative_scenarios.impact: Safer daylight travel; gives time for treatment of neighborhoods and lots.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Full closure (widespread glaze/crash clusters or multi-building power/heat issues)

for_schools: Plan around a likely slick 6:00–8:00 AM window; pre-stage salt/sand for entrances, bus loops, sidewalks, and known refreeze zones.
If early AM spotter reports show widespread slickness on neighborhood streets/rural connectors, strongly consider a 2-hour delay rather than waiting for incident confirmation.
Monitor NWS/MDOT updates and any overnight crash clusters between ~4:30–6:30 AM; be ready to message families quickly.
for_residents: Assume bridges/ramps and subdivision streets may be icy 6:00–8:00 AM even if highways look fine; slow down and increase following distance.
Dress for cold but not extreme wind chills; minimize waiting time at bus stops and keep phone contact plans for delays.
If you encounter glare ice, report it to local road agencies (and adjust routes away from hills/bridges).
for_authorities: Prioritize bridge decks, ramps, and school approach roads pre-6 AM; use abrasives where salt efficacy is limited by cold pavement.
If feasible, add an early pass on rural bus-route corridors north/east of Rockford before 7 AM.
Coordinate quick situational awareness (crashes, slick spot hotspots) with dispatch and share with district operations early.

positions.rationale:
Net meteorological picture for Rockford, MI on Tuesday 2026-01-27 is “low accumulation + cold + possible patchy ice near daybreak.” That combination elevates the *delay* risk more than the *closure* risk. With only ~0.45" snow forecast and winds below major blowing/drifting thresholds, I can’t justify a high closure probability. I am, however, above a ‘baseline nuisance snow day’ because the freezing-rain windows (especially near ~06:00) are timed right at bus rollout/early commute and could create patchy black ice that forces a conservative call.

So I land at ~22% for a full snow day (closure). If your system distinguishes outcomes, I’d put the *2-hour delay* probability meaningfully higher than the closure probability.
keyFactors: Snow totals are light for West Michigan standards (~1.15 cm / 0.45"), with the main snow window ~03:00–05:00; by typical closure thresholds, this alone is unlikely to cancel school.

A brief wintry-mix/icing signal exists ("light freezing rain" around ~02:00 and again ~06:00). Even very small glaze amounts can create disproportionate AM-commute risk on bridges/overpasses and untreated neighborhood streets.
Temperatures stay well below freezing all day (low ~1°F, high ~16°F), so any untreated moisture/compaction won’t melt off and can remain slick into bus-run time.
Wind is moderate (sustained ~15–19 mph, gusts low-to-mid 20s mph). This supports some wind-chill stress and limited blowing snow, but not classic blizzard/drifting conditions.

Visibility: overnight vis ~1 mile in the precip window is plausible; however, the repeated 0-mile daytime visibility entries look like a data artifact and shouldn’t be treated as a true whiteout signal.

Cold Weather Advisory (through 9:00 AM Tue) supports a meaningful wind-chill hazard during bus-stop hours, but the forecast wind chills in the payload are mostly around ~-5°F to ~-10°F (borderline for “cold-only” closures; more often a delay/mitigation response than a full cancel).

positions.rationale: Putting the *history lens* on the forecast for Tuesday, January 27, 2026: the snowfall amount (~0.45") aligns with a pattern that rarely yields full cancellations in West Michigan. The main historical driver that can “punch above its weight” is a brief ice/glaze event landing right before the AM commute; that pushes me out of the single digits, but not into a high-probability closure scenario. I’m landing at **18%** for a full snow day (closure), with the stronger outcome being **normal operations or a delay** if icing verifies on untreated roads/bridges.
keyFactors: **Historical closure thresholds (West Michigan, late January):** A forecast around ~0.45" snow (≈1.15 cm) is usually a “nuisance” event that districts in the Grand Rapids/Rockford area typically *do not* close for by itself.

**Timing risk is real but narrow:** The worst window is pre-dawn (roughly 2:00–6:30 AM) with light snow plus brief freezing-rain/freezing-drizzle signals. Historically, *thin glaze at the wrong time* is more likely to produce a **delay** than a full closure unless it becomes widespread/confirmed on roads.

**Cold/wind chill is near (not beyond) common closure triggers:** The provided WeatherAPI-style values suggest wind chills roughly in the -5°F to -15°F neighborhood around the morning window—this is uncomfortable and can drive operational caution, but historically many districts don’t close purely for that unless it’s more like ≤ -15°F widespread/prolonged (especially closer to -20°F).

**Local variability (lake-effect / microclimate):** Rockford can be on the edge of sharper gradients; if a band sets up over bus-route corridors, localized whiteout/slick travel can outpace the “total accumulation” number. But the forecast totals and wind don’t scream “district-wide shutdown.”

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint for Tuesday, 2026-01-27 in Rockford, MI, the overnight hazard profile is “high-impact/low-quantity”: light snow + brief freezing rain can create slick spots right before the morning commute even with low totals. That said, totals and wind aren’t at classic closure thresholds for West Michigan, and conditions appear to improve after sunrise. This pattern more often yields a DELAY than a full cancellation, unless icing verifies as widespread (not just patchy). I therefore place full snow-day probability in the high-teens, with the caveat that verification of glazing/crash clusters could push this up quickly overnight/early morning.
keyFactors: Primary closure driver here isn’t snow depth (only ~0.45 in / 1.15 cm total), it’s **slickness risk** from a narrow pre-dawn wintry-mix window (freezing rain signal ~2 AM and again ~6 AM) overlapping the bus-rollout/commute window.

**Temps stay well below freezing all day** (high ~16°F, low ~1°F). Any treatment “wins” are slower and any melt/refreeze cycles create persistent black-ice on untreated/shaded spots (bridges/ramps/parking lots).

**Wind chills are hazardous but borderline for “cold-only” closure**: forecast wind chills around ~0°F to roughly -10°F-ish during the morning (per WeatherAPI), which more often supports operational tweaks (shorter outdoor waits, caution for walkers) than a full closure.

**Road network asymmetry:** main arterials likely improved by/after daybreak; risk concentrates on neighborhood/rural connectors used by bus routes and on school lots/drop-offs where a thin glaze causes disproportionate incident risk.
No strong “domino” signal yet (no official RPS closure posted at time of scan), and winds are modest (not a drifting/whiteout day).

positions.rationale: From a news/operations standpoint, I weight (1) presence/absence of official closure messaging, (2) whether neighboring districts are starting to move (domino effect), and (3) whether there’s a clearly disruptive hazard likely to become headline news by early morning (major ice storm, widespread outages, significant snow totals, or confirmed travel chaos). For Tuesday, Jan 27, 2026 in Rockford, the weather looks like a high-friction *morning* (possible patchy glaze + very cold wind chills), but not a classic ‘close everything’ setup given low snow totals and modest winds. With no confirmed district announcements yet and no outage-driven narrative, I’m at a low-to-low-moderate closure probability, with the main upside risk being if the freezing-rain window verifies worse than expected right before buses roll.
keyFactors: No official Rockford Public Schools closure/delay message visible yet for Tue, Jan 27, 2026; districts often post by late evening if they already intend to close, so “silence so far” weakly favors open (but isn’t decisive).
Forecast impact window is mainly pre-dawn (about 2:00–6:30 AM) with a mixed-precip/icing signal and only ~0.45" snow equivalent—this is more consistent with a *delay* trigger than a full-day closure.

Cold Weather Advisory overlaps the morning commute (through 9:00 AM Tue). Wind chills in the payload are very uncomfortable and can influence decisions, but are near the ‘gray zone’ for closures in West Michigan unless they’re worse than forecast or combined with ice.

No strong “domino effect” confirmation: I did not see neighboring districts posting Tue closures yet. In this region, widespread closures often show up across multiple districts and TV-station closing lists early.
Power grid signal is not pointing to a widespread outage event (systemwide outages low). Without outage clusters, a closure for facilities/heat is less likely.

debates.topic: The historical wind-chill closure threshold discussion is helpful, but it may underplay the advisory timing (through 9 AM) and operational realities (bus-stop exposure, diesel/bus issues). Still, the payload wind chills don’t scream ‘automatic closure.’

debates.topic: We should explicitly discount the ‘0-mile visibility’ daytime hours as likely bad data; if treated as real, it would incorrectly inflate closure odds.
debates.challenge: We should explicitly discount the ‘0-mile visibility’ daytime hours as likely bad data; if treated as real, it would incorrectly inflate closure odds.

debates.topic: The 0-mile daytime visibility entries look like a data artifact (as you noted). I’d challenge using those directly as a closure signal unless corroborated by precip/fog fields or a consistent hour-by-hour narrative. Also, the ‘daily_will_it_snow=0’ versus ‘moderate/heavy snow showers’ plus ~1.15 cm totals is internally inconsistent and suggests classification/aggregation issues.
debates.challenge: The 0-mile daytime visibility entries look like a data artifact (as you noted). I’d challenge using those directly as a closure signal unless corroborated by precip/fog fields or a consistent hour-by-hour narrative. Also, the ‘daily_will_it_snow=0’ versus ‘moderate/heavy snow showers’ plus ~1.15 cm totals is internally inconsistent and suggests classification/aggregation issues.

debates.topic: You label ice formation risk as “high,” which may be directionally right, but the provided precip amounts for freezing rain are extremely small (e.g., 0.01–0.08 mm/hr). Historically, ‘high’ ice risk is most justified when there’s clearer evidence of measurable glaze or temps near 32°F with refreeze. Here it’s very cold, so any liquid freezes fast—but the question is whether enough liquid falls to matter. I’d want that uncertainty reflected (e.g., ‘moderate-to-high if freezing drizzle verifies’).
debates.challenge: You label ice formation risk as “high,” which may be directionally right, but the provided precip amounts for freezing rain are extremely small (e.g., 0.01–0.08 mm/hr). Here it’s very cold, so any liquid freezes fast—but the question is whether enough liquid falls to matter. I’d want that uncertainty reflected (e.g., ‘moderate-to-high if freezing drizzle verifies’).

debates.topic: No closure post yet is weak evidence either way (many districts decide late evening/early AM). The stronger historical signal would be *confirmed neighboring-district decisions for Tue 1/27* (domino effect), which currently seems absent/uncertain in your scan.
debates.challenge: No closure post yet is weak evidence either way (many districts decide late evening/early AM). The stronger historical signal would be *confirmed neighboring-district decisions for Tue 1/27* (domino effect), which currently seems absent/uncertain in your scan.

debates.topic: We may be underweighting the **freezing-drizzle/freezing-rain impact** versus snowfall totals. Even trace glaze can drive closure decisions if it hits 5–7 AM. I’d like a clearer estimate of likely glaze magnitude and surface temps (pavement) during 2–7 AM.
debates.challenge: We may be underweighting the **freezing-drizzle/freezing-rain impact** versus snowfall totals. Even trace glaze can drive closure decisions if it hits 5–7 AM. I’d like a clearer estimate of likely glaze magnitude and surface temps (pavement) during 2–7 AM.

debates.topic: Historical rates given (5–12%) may be too low for **ice-timing** scenarios. The timing here (pre-dawn) is exactly when districts act conservatively due to bus safety; history should separate ‘light snow’ days from ‘trace ice at commute’ days more explicitly.
debates.challenge: Historical rates given (5–12%) may be too low for **ice-timing** scenarios. The timing here (pre-dawn) is exactly when districts act conservatively due to bus safety; history should separate ‘light snow’ days from ‘trace ice at commute’ days more explicitly.

debates.topic: ‘No closure posted yet’ is a weak negative signal because many districts decide late night/early AM. More useful would be: any **neighboring district early decisions**, and any road commission/MDOT incident reports overnight.
debates.challenge: ‘No closure posted yet’ is a weak negative signal because many districts decide late night/early AM. More useful would be: any **neighboring district early decisions**, and any road commission/MDOT incident reports overnight.

debates.topic: The precipitation-type/amount story looks internally inconsistent: the daily summary says 0.45" snow and only 19% snow chance, but several overnight hours show 92–100% snow chance plus a freezing-rain label. If that hourly mix is a model artifact or timing shifts later (into 6–8 AM), the operational impact could be higher than framed—worth sanity-checking against an NWS hourly grid/point forecast.

debates.topic: High ice-formation risk is plausible, but the dataset’s precip amounts are tiny (e.g., 0.01–0.08 mm in the freezing-rain hours). If that’s truly the magnitude, the ‘high’ label may be overstated unless we expect untreated surfaces + refreeze to dominate. I’d like clearer linkage: what glaze thickness or road-temp assumption drives ‘high’?

debates.topic: The wind-chill closure threshold framing may be too rigid. Districts sometimes close for cold at warmer wind chills if it’s prolonged, coincides with other hazards (slick roads), or follows recent cold-related closures (as with Forest Hills on Fri, Jan 23, 2026). Historical rates should incorporate that “recency/precedent” effect.

debates.topic: WebWeatherVerifier flags a big discrepancy with Weather.com ‘feels like -23 to -24°F’ on at least one listing, but those pages were crawled ‘last week’ and may be mismatched (wrong Rockford, wrong day, or outdated). Until reconciled with an authoritative point forecast (NWS) or current local TV weather, I would not let that swing the closure probability too high.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason:
Net meteorological picture for Rockford, MI on Tuesday 2026-01-27 is “low accumulation + cold + possible patchy ice near daybreak.” That combination elevates the *delay* risk more than the *closure* risk. With only ~0.45" snow forecast and winds below major blowing/drifting thresholds, I can’t justify a high closure probability. I am, however, above a ‘baseline nuisance snow day’ because the freezing-rain windows (especially near ~06:00) are timed right at bus rollout/early commute and could create patchy black ice that forces a conservative call.

So I land at ~22% for a full snow day (closure). If your system distinguishes outcomes, I’d put the *2-hour delay* probability meaningfully higher than the closure probability.

Putting the *history lens* on the forecast for Tuesday, January 27, 2026: the snowfall amount (~0.45") aligns with a pattern that rarely yields full cancellations in West Michigan. The main historical driver that can “punch above its weight” is a brief ice/glaze event landing right before the AM commute; that pushes me out of the single digits, but not into a high-probability closure scenario. I’m landing at **18%** for a full snow day (closure), with the stronger outcome being **normal operations or a delay** if icing verifies on untreated roads/bridges.

From a safety standpoint for Tuesday, 2026-01-27 in Rockford, MI, the overnight hazard profile is “high-impact/low-quantity”: light snow + brief freezing rain can create slick spots right before the morning commute even with low totals. That said, totals and wind aren’t at classic closure thresholds for West Michigan, and conditions appear to improve after sunrise. This pattern more often yields a DELAY than a full cancellation, unless icing verifies as widespread (not just patchy). I therefore place full snow-day probability in the high-teens, with the caveat that verification of glazing/crash clusters could push this up quickly overnight/early morning.

From a news/operations standpoint, I weight (1) presence/absence of official closure messaging, (2) whether neighboring districts are starting to move (domino effect), and (3) whether there’s a clearly disruptive hazard likely to become headline news by early morning (major ice storm, widespread outages, significant snow totals, or confirmed travel chaos). For Tuesday, Jan 27, 2026 in Rockford, the weather looks like a high-friction *morning* (possible patchy glaze + very cold wind chills), but not a classic ‘close everything’ setup given low snow totals and modest winds. With no confirmed district announcements yet and no outage-driven narrative, I’m at a low-to-low-moderate closure probability, with the main upside risk being if the freezing-rain window verifies worse than expected right before buses roll.

keyDisagreements.topic: The absence of a closure post on the district homepage isn’t strong evidence either way (many districts post late evening/early AM). Treat it as weak/neutral rather than leaning it toward “open.”
positions: The absence of a closure post on the district homepage isn’t strong evidence either way (many districts post late evening/early AM). Treat it as weak/neutral rather than leaning it toward “open.”

keyDisagreements.topic: “Ice formation risk: high” feels directionally right, but without an estimated glaze amount or confidence on freezing-rain intensity, it may overweight a very light/freezing-drizzle scenario that districts often manage with treatment + delay.

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 4.0% spread. Average probability: 20%.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 26 at 10:14AM EST until January 27 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 17 below expected.

* WHERE...Calhoun, Clinton, Eaton, Ingham, Ionia, Jackson, Allegan,
Barry, Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...From 7 PM this evening to 9 AM EST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...The cold wind chills as low as 15 below zero could
result in hypothermia or frostbite if precautions are not taken.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 26 at 10:14AM EST until January 26 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch.

* WHERE...Allegan and Ottawa Counties.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
continue to be slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow.
alert.instruction:
During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 25 at 4:08PM EST until January 26 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Monday.

* IMPACTS...Low lying areas along the Muskegon River that are prone
to flooding may see rapidly changing water levels.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 406 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Sunday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. Flooding due
to freeze-up ice jams is typically minor, but can be
unpredictable.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
